NewsCitiesAhmedabadPower outage in Surat till Saturday due to scheduled pre-monsoon maintenance work
Power outage in Surat till Saturday due to scheduled pre-monsoon maintenance work
The power outages will impact feeders under various subdivisions in Surat. According to a notice issued by the Surat Rural division office of the DGVCL, the subdivisions where the power outages will occur include Kapodara, Pasodara, Kosad, Puna, Simada and Laskana.
By: Express News Service
Surat | June 12, 2025 00:55 IST
2 min read
Power outage will also be experienced in the industrial areas in Surat district, like Kadodara, which will affect multiple subdivisions, including Kadodara Industrial, Kamrej Rural, Kamrej 2, Kadodara 1, Sevni, Kadodara 2 and Palsana.

Several areas in Surat have been witnessing power cuts from 7 am to 12 pm since Monday owing to scheduled maintenance work, as announced by the Dakshin Gujarat Vij Company Limited (DGVCL). The maintenance work will go on till Saturday, with sources saying that this is part of pre-monsoon preparations being taken in the state.

The power outages will impact feeders under various subdivisions in Surat. According to a notice issued by the Surat Rural division office of the DGVCL, the subdivisions where the power outages will occur include Kapodara, Pasodara, Kosad, Puna, Simada and Laskana.

On Monday, the 11 KV Shubhlaxmi Industrial feeder from the 66 kV Kadodara sub-station will experience a power outage. On Tuesday, multiple areas, such as all 11 kV feeders under the 66 kV Vav sub-station in Kamrej Rural, and the 11 kV Khaleshwar AG feeder from the 66 kV Kamrej sub-station under the Kamrej-2 Urban sub-division was affected. Power was disrupted in several locations, including the 11 kV Maruti Industrial feeder, 11 kV Jay Bharat Industrial feeder, 11 kV Nagod AG feeder, and 11 kV Galateshwar JGY feeder on Wednesday.

STORY CONTINUES BELOW THIS AD

On Thursday, affected feeders will include the 11 kV Bindal Industrial feeder in Kadodara-1, the 11 kV Dastan JGY feeder from the 66 kV Jolva sub-station under Kadodara-2, the 11 kV Bhavani JGY feeder from the 66 kV Kamrej sub-station in Kamrej Rural, and the 11 kV Delad AG feeder in Kamrej-2 Urban. Further outages will take place on Friday, affecting the 11 kV Morthana AG feeder and 11 kV Parab JGY feeder from the 66 kV Parab sub-station in Sevni, along with the 11 kV Jiyor AG feeder under Kamrej-2 Urban from the 66 kV Kamrej sub-station. Outages are scheduled for the 11 kV Nehrunagar Industrial feeder from the 66 kV Kamrej sub-station in Kamrej Rural, and all 11 kV feeders from the 66 kV Palsana sub-station, affecting the Palsana sub-division on Saturday.

Power outage will also be experienced in the industrial areas in Surat district, like Kadodara, which will affect multiple subdivisions, including Kadodara Industrial, Kamrej Rural, Kamrej 2, Kadodara 1, Sevni, Kadodara 2 and Palsana.

Sources said that due to such outages, many textile factories in Palsana, Kamrej, and Kadodara are expected to face financial loss as production will be hampered.

GHMC, HYDRAA join hands to combat waterlogging
The Hans India
Hans News Service | 12 Jun 2025 10:35 AM IST
HIGHLIGHTS
Hyderabad: In preparation for the monsoon season, the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC), in collaboration with the Hyderabad Disaster...

Hyderabad: In preparation for the monsoon season, the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC), in collaboration with the Hyderabad Disaster Response and Asset Protection Agency (HYDRAA), has intensified efforts to prevent urban flooding and deployed emergency teams across the city.

A total of 130 monsoon emergency teams, each comprising 12 personnel, are being deployed under GHMC‚Äôs jurisdiction. Additionally, 51 Disaster Response Force (DRF) teams from HYDRAA, each with 15 members, will be deployed to support these units.

During a review meeting held at the Municipal Secretary‚Äôs office on Wednesday, officials reiterated that the main objective is to ensure the public faces no inconvenience during the rainy season, with both HYDRAA and GHMC working to minimise flood risks.

In this initiative, teams from both GHMC and HYDRAA will operate under the direct supervision of HYDRAA authorities to ensure a prompt response during waterlogging incidents. These teams will be deployed in flood-prone areas and will spring into action whenever water stagnation is reported, particularly in residential areas, with their collaborative efforts aimed at facilitating smooth traffic flow and mitigating the risk of flooding.

While GHMC will take charge of removing silt and debris from sewers, HYDRAA will offer logistics and manpower assistance as needed. The responsibility for managing the operations of monsoon emergency teams now lies with HYDRAA.
